plist.p: Good morning. This is the Chorus Call conference operator. Welcome and thank you for joining the UniCredit Group First Quarter 2009 Results Conference Call. As a reminder, all participants are in listen-only mode. After the presentation, there will be an opportunity to ask questions. .
At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. Alessandro Profumo, CEO of UniCredit Group. Please go ahead, sir.

So good morning to everybody. Many thanks for being connected to us. Shall we start immediately at page three of the presentation with executive summary? First of all, the net profit, 447 million in the first quarter in a still challenging environment, mainly based on a very good performance on the operating profit level where we have a growth quarter-on-quarter of 44% and year-on-year of 18.6%, which would be 52 respectively and 27% at constant forex and perimeter. This result has been achieved thanks to the diversification and cost control. The priority on cost control is giving good result with operating cost down by 2.8% year-on-year at constant forex and perimeter. It would be 6.4% quarter-on-quarter. The reduction on total and trading assets is ongoing. We are down 2.9 and 8.9% quarter-on-quarter respectively net of hedging instruments. The core Tier 1 at the end of the first quarter is at 6.38 with organic growth, which has been offset by specific factors, party reversed in the second quarter to date. The specific factors are the forex in Central Eastern Europe plus the available-for-sales reserve. Underlying profitability is still providing us very strong loss absorption capacity.

Going to page four and talking on the operating profit, as you can see we have a good performance both on the commercial banking and on the MIB side. Commercial banking is still – is quite resilient. We are down 89 million quarter-on-quarter, which would be plus 28 million at constant forex. Clearly the forex devaluation in Central Eastern Europe had a significant impact on gross operating profit. I would like also to remember the fact that the first quarter do have two days less than the fourth quarter of the year. So today is 2.3%, which do have a direct impact on net interest margins. MIB is back to profit with a net profit in the first quarter of €367 million.

Clearly a significant contribution to this good operating profit results, going to page five is provided by the cost savings. We will have some further detail in this page, but also in the following pages. At year-on-year, we are down by 2.8% with a significant reduction on the staff cost 4.2% and a reduction on the other cost as well minus 0.5%. Quarter-on-quarter, we are down by 6.4% thanks to both staff reduction as well as other cost. As you can see, on the second half of the page, the contribution to the growth of the operating income is coming partially from revenues as well as from cost.

If we go to page six, we are seeing what has been done in terms of staff rightsizing. We are down by 3,800 people more or less in the first quarter with a good contribution from all the division of the group. Clearly retail is the main contributor, thanks to the delivery of the synergies of the Capitalia, integration. CEE is also reducing. You remember that we said that we would change the focus in Central Eastern Europe from growth to cost control. You see that the revenues are still performing really well in Central Eastern Europe. But also the cost control is undergoing, then we have a good contribution of MIB, Asset Management, Corporate Center and the rest .

If we move to page seven, I'm talking of other costs. Clearly here we have to split the reduction in different elements. We have, what we call, cyclical elements that are – who are related mainly to forex effect, but as well as to other minor effects. And we have fractional items where clearly the reduction is related to activities that will continue to have a positive impact as well as in the future.

Moving to page eight, clearly the asset quality is one of the key topics. There is a deterioration which was expected due to the economic cycle. As you can see, the non-performing loans are quite stable. We have a small reduction of 0.2%. We have a significant growth in the other gross impaired loans, which are mainly watchlist, a 23.99% growth. Clearly, this is due to the negative cycle which is having an impact on the quality of the portfolios. We are in line with what the model it would consider as expected losses in relation to the GDP growth – better decrease, sorry.

Page nine, coverage ratio; there is a significant growth of the coverage ratio on the NPLs. There is a small reduction on the other impaired. Overall, there is a reduction due to the fact that we have growth only in the other impaired loans where clearly the coverage ratio is lower, so the weighted average is lower than the previous quarter. That is mainly due to this mix effect or mainly – only due to this mix effect. The group risk is stable quarter-on-quarter. You remember that in the first quarter last year we had a stated of 86 basis points and we had and we had communicated transparently the 300 million of write-backs in Germany for the RER portfolio -- that write-backs we freed up reserve. So the cost of risk was 105; we are at 109 in this quarter.

Moving to page – to the following page, page 10. We are – we have the concept of loss absorption capacity, which is a concept we have talked of in the last presentation. We are quite stable and very strong in terms of loss absorption capacity. It is at 232 basis points at the Group level you have to compare with 109 we were talking before with 186 in Western Europe and 524 in Central Eastern Europe.

If we move to page 11, is a clear demonstration of the fact that the leveraging is ongoing. We have a small decrease in terms of total assets when we consider also the derivative instruments where the growth is only related to volatility. As you know, on the liability side we have slightly more than what we have on the asset side in this . So when we consider the cash assets or the assets funded we are down by 2.9% at €898 billion, which is a continuous, significant reduction. It is also very important to say that the tangible equity – and I'd like to remember that for us tangible equity is also excluding other intangibles, not always. This is calculated in a similar way by all our competitors, is quite stable at €2.19 per share. So it is at a very, very stable level. When we talk of the leverage ratio, our leverage ratio is improving a little bit. We are at 29.1 in the first quarter. If we would net the hedging instruments over the portion that could be netted in the case of a central counterpart, we would at 26.3% which is again a quite comfortable level.

At page 12, we have the reduction in trading assets. As you can see we are going down in all the lines, so we are stable on government bonds, corporate debt, and securities is down – sorry, it's important to say that we have reclassified 9.3 billion in this quarter, with a really negligible impact on the profit and loss. The reclassification is due to the fact that there are no trades at all so our completely liquid assets, but there is no impact on the profit and loss as far as this reclassification. But even without this reclassification, the corporate debt and securities are down by 5.2 billion. Then we have a reduction as well in the traded loans and in others. So overall the reduction is 8.8% in the other assets.

Capital position, we were already stating the fact that it is at 6.38. The reduction we – you will see the reduction to what is due on the following page. Overall, we would be with the government bonds above 7% in terms of core Tier 1 and 28% in terms of total capital in terms of Tier 1 – sorry, Tier 1 ratio. The risk-weighted assets are still going down significantly by 1.7%, which is quite a good result.

In page 14, we are explaining the reduction of the core Tier 1; 08 bps are due to – of reduction to the forex effect, which is again partially recovered in the second quarter – five basis points have been recovered, mainly on the zloty. Then we have 06 basis points for the available-for-sales reserve and again accounted that in – only in Italy, Portugal, and Spain this available-for-sale reserve negative must be deducted from the capital. Five basis points are related to Generali, of which three basis points have been already recovered in the second quarter, and then we have the positive contribution from the reduction of risk weighted asset and from the net earnings reduction of net Basel additions.

Now shall we move to some more detailed numbers? So I move to page 16. Here we have the profit and loss line-by-line and as usual we have the quarter-on-quarter changes and year-on-year change and then year-on-year normalized which means at constant forex and perimeter. Starting from the revenues, the revenues are up by 8% quarter-on-quarter and year-on-year 1.8%, but if you would consider again normalized is 8.1%. The costs are down, so the operating profit is significantly growing. The net write-downs are going up quite significantly, as expected with this economic cycle. The other non-operating items are reduced compared to the previous year. Income tax is quite high, the tax rate is 36%, mainly due to the IRAP effect in Italy. As you know, the IRAP is effectively a labor tax which is flat in relation to the labor cost. So that we go to the net profit of 447 million.

Moving to page 17 and considering the profit and loss line-by-line. I want to immediately say that clearly we had a very good resilience of the net interest income, if we compare the year-on-year results and the quarter-on-quarter. We had a strong contribution of MIB where – with a portion of the net interest margin which is related to trading activities. So in reality as all – many our competitors are doing for MIB would be better to consider the total revenues and not splitting of trading income and net interest. With the interest rate curve which is deepening, clearly you can book some deal on one side or on the other side. The net commissions are affected by the reduction of assets under management. This is the main impact on the year-on-year reduction. When we talk of quarter-on-quarter, there are also other components because, for instance, in corporate, the fourth quarter has been a very good quarter in terms of fees in corporate finance. This is due to seasonalities so that in the first quarter we had a reduction. Trading income, as I've said before, a very significant improvement positive if we would consider the portion which is booked as well in the interest margin.

When we go to the following page, page 18, you see the main – the revenues in MIB that came back to a black figure in all the lines despite of the high credit spreads. So in the different business lines we came back to profit.

Cost, page 19, here we have the split of Western Europe and CE. As we said, we have a very good reduction at the group level on year-on-year. Quarter-on-quarter also in Italy we have a reduction, normalized, clearly when we consider the year-on-year is a growth rate – a growth because of the fact that in Central Eastern Europe we had in the last quarter the opening of branches. But when we go to the quarter-on-quarter it is reduced as well in Central Eastern Europe.

Page 20, operating profit, as we said the operating profit is quite stable in the commercial banking. If we wouldn't consider the forex effects and the one-off we had in retail in the last quarter, we would be positive by 1% in commercial banking. Clearly, the non-comparable in MIB where we had a loss in the first quarter while we were in the first quarter of this year. Asset management is still affected by the reduction in assets under management, so we have a reduction in terms of operating profit of 31% quarter-on-quarter. Central Eastern Europe, which apparently is down by 2.4%, at constant forex it would be up by 10%, so it is quite a good result.

Moving to the following page we have the cost of risk at divisional level. As we said, we are almost stable quarter-on-quarter with some delta in the different divisions. Retail is slightly growing due to a deterioration in Italy. This is due mainly to small business. Corporate is stable at 100 basis point. There is a significant reduction in MIB and a growth in Central Eastern Europe from 115 to 170 basis points. We have to consider this is a weighted average of an improved Poland with a deterioration in the other countries. Poland is being excellent in terms of quality of our assets.

Page 22 I think has been described before. I want to only to recall your attention to the tax rate which is 36%, and which is expected to remain relatively higher than the previous year during also the following quarters.

If we move to page 23, we had the reclassification of this 9.4 billion of assets. As I said, the impact on the profit and loss is completely negligible; are mainly composed of government bonds, as you can see in the first bullet point, second line. This is – and covered bond as well. So it's really a matter of liquidity; it's not a matter of quality.
Now I have finished my presentation and with the colleagues we are open to all your questions.
Excuse me, this is the Chorus Call conference operator. We are now – we will now begin the question-and-answer session. . The first question is from Mr. Marcello Zanardo of KBW. Please go ahead, sir.

Good morning, Mr. Profumo, to you and to all your colleague there. The first question is actually on the positive surprise on the results which is on cost. There was some forex effect as you mentioned, but could you tell us what you are implementing in the last three or four months? Clearly the environment is now getting better. So give us a bit more details, for instance, on the merger between the CAB, the investment banking division and the corporate division, the closure of branches and so on? And should we assume this cost basically to have lower seasonality versus last year?

The second questions is on trading income, there was pick up on the revenue environment in the investment banking division, but a lot of your competitors posted a much better trading income versus your loss. I mean what is driving this loss? Actually these two questions only. Thank you.

On the cost side then I can leave the floor to Sergio Ermotti in order to answer on the trading income. On the cost side, I think, that we have to go back, Marcello, to page six and seven, because we have relatively clearly explain. Page six gives you a view on the staff reductions, which is quite significant. So we have speed up the process of rightsizing, which clearly will have an effect – a stable effect during the year, because you start from a lower level. In the staff cost – in the staff cost there is reduction. There is more or less 40 million, which is cyclical because it is related to the fact that we had a lower impact versus previous year of the MBO system. We close all the incentive plan in March with the approval of the year-end results. So we book the cost every year in a conservative way and then we release in the first quarter what is not paid. So on the staff cost this is – the portion that in the first quarter is "cyclical".

Talking of page seven, you have a very clear view of what we call cyclical and structural, so – which is very clearly defined. The structural costs are related to internal and external communication; the advertising, traveling, consulting, so many different elements plus some ICT savings we had. So clearly, we are working structurally on a lower base also versus the banking. Talking of trading income, as I said before, it's not proper to see trading income splitted from net interest margin , but we leave the floor to Sergio Ermotti.

In addition to what Mr. Profumo just said, which has substantial impact on our trading results offset by the net interest line, we have to clearly highlight that the first quarter was still a very stressful quarter for all high rated paper, including government bonds, covered bonds and we have substantial spread widening there. So – which was to a big extent offset by gains in the basis risk, CDS versus cash items. So when we look at credit market related activity, we had major volatility in different asset classes, more or less offsetting each other, and therefore creating this number – this net result. I think we had a favorable environment in equities compared to the fourth quarter. So overall, again, I think I would say a successful environment for trading, but still not without any major surprises coming from credit spreads widening in higher rated asset classes.

So if I understood correctly, going back to cost, sorry, for a minute. The net of the FX effect this year, we should not expect a high volatility such as in the last quarter of the year. We will have a big pick up in the cost because you're structurally lowering the cost base throughout the year. Is it a correct assumption?
Yes.

Okay. And sorry just looked at some new data now, also if I may, the very last question. Clearly the cost of risk -- the watchlist increase has been quite significant, as you pointed out 76% year-on-year. And the coverage there is lower and also on the gross restructuring loans, you said Italy retail is one of the area, the small business clearly. Looking on page...
And small corporate as well.
And corporate as well. I am looking at...
Small corporate.

Yeah. Okay. I'm looking at page 21 where you show your cost of risk by division. First of all, the big drop in MIB, there were some big before. What are you seeing in the MIB division going forward? Especially look at your leverage loan book that you have there is it still – I guess it's still performing, but if you could give us a little bit more of color what you've said on this area which clearly is quite difficult to make some forecast given the seriousness of the crisis and such a big loan book that you have?

Well. On the LBO portfolio, first of all clearly we are taking some increased provisions due to the generics, but at this point in time there is negligible provision made on single names are particularly all major positions, our big positions we have are still performing and they are not in any areas of breach of covenants or any close to that. So, for the time being we are comfortable, but clearly if we have this GDP forecast figures for the year being confirmed or into 2010, we may see some need of impairments of positions. But at this point in time, again, there is no – we feel very comfortable with the quality of the underlying names.
And in the corporate division, what are you seeing. I see the cost of risk gets stable basically from Q4?

Well, cost of risk is stable but clearly if you look into the different countries and the different segments, there is a high degree of volatility clearly. Large corporates are performing relatively well compared to the small names. We see a stable environment in Germany for the time being and also stable environment in Austria. I think Italy is much more challenging.
Okay. Thank you very much.
The next question is from Mr. Alessandro Roccati of Fox-Pitt, Kelton. Please go ahead, sir.

Hi, good morning, everyone. I've got three questions. The first one is back on the cost of risk and more specifically in Italy retail where the cost of risk was 131 basis points and in corporates where it was 147 basis points. Just wondering whether you can expand on that? The increase has been quite significant, both year-on-year and quarter-on-quarter.

The second question is on the MIB division or revenues and in particular on the market division. I've seen quite poor performance in rates and forex 170 million revenues, 300 million was the figure last quarter. your competitors are actually seeing a steady increase of almost 100% in these divisions, and I believe that going forward FICC is going to be one of the drivers of growth in the CIB division. I'm just wondering whether you think you'll be able to benefit from these strength going forward or you will lag compared to competitors?

And finally the last question is on the reclassification of the division of profit and loss. I'm just wondering why you made this reclassification and what are the major changes, the purpose? Thank you.

So I can start with the second question. And basically when you look at the rates and FX, you are right to point out that we had a decrease quarter-on-quarter compared to the market strength. But one issue to be noted is that a lot of the spread widening on and highly rated quality paper is part of this business segment to manage liquidity, and therefore we suffered the mark-to-market on this position. Compared to standard and that's the reason why we are – we moved it to – from held for trading to loan and receivables because it is, as you may know, is market standard to not to hold in trading -- these positions are for liquidity reason. And therefore, we created a mark-to-market effect which is not, I would say, industry comparable to other players.

So from that standpoint, it explains a one-off drop in revenues quarter-on-quarter. We do expect, as we see in the second quarter, the rates business and FX business to still continue to contribute a stable revenue pattern for the rest of the year. And the question regarding why we reclassified is that despite the fact that we are talking about covered bonds, government bonds and so on, in some of these asset classes there is lack of liquidity and again the mark-to-market volatility was not any longer in line with our intent. The intent of this position is not really to trade but it's to hold it for liquidity purposes. Therefore, having P&L swings coming from trading for some things that we deem to be – to be hold to maturity for liquidity management was not appropriate.
Roberto.

Yes, as far as – as far as retail is concerned, the delta is ascribed to two phenomenon. On one side, when you look at Germany, you have a movement from actual write-backs, net write-backs, at Q4 of minus 16 basis points; that came to a kind of normal 38 basis points level. So clearly in terms of delta plays an important part.

The other – the second factor is Italy. In Italy, what we have currently are two phenomenon. On one side we have a slight increase of mortgage. But the increase in cost of risk of mortgage is now plateauing. In reality, we had the peak of increases in regular loans in January. But then all the flows are becoming steady and actually slightly even decreasing in the last weeks, while instead we have seen an increase in the small business provisioning level. Moving forward, we tend to see a kind of stability with mortgage, possibly a reduction in the small business, possibly instead increasing. It will depend clearly on the depth of the recession in the next quarter.
And just going back to the cost of risk in corporate Italy which was 147 basis points, I think is quite high compared to your comparison. Just wondering whether you can make a comment on that please?

I think that here there are two effects. First of all, clearly we have a deterioration and which is clearly reflected in the numbers. And second we also had – we implemented towards the end of March a new model for generic reserves and classification, which created, I would say, what we can call a one-off situation. So I would expect – as we are expecting this number to come down in the second quarter.
Thank you.
The next question is from Mr. Matteo Ramenghi of UBS. Please go ahead, sir.

Yes. Good morning to everyone. Just three quick questions on provision. First of all on Poland, clearly the assets you have are of very high quality. But I was wondering what is the run rate you expect for provisions, because if I look at the recent past I think we were looking at 42 bps in Q1 and then average of 15 in the last four quarters?

Then on leasing instead there was a sharp increase in cost of credit, I think it threefold quarter-on-quarter to 109 basis points. And I was wondering if you could give a bit more color on the break down by geography or by sector or whatever you see the deterioration coming?
And again on provisions, just to make sure I understood well, the cost of credit of 69 bps that was including the charges on the LBO portfolio. And I was wondering if there was any update on that?

And then finally moving to fees in retail, I think there was an increase quarter-on-quarter in Italy and Germany, and I was wondering if it is related to upfront fees or rather to – there are some change in trends? Thank you.

On Poland, this is the trend. The quality of the assets are really good, so we are not foreseeing deterioration. On the contrary we had some small improvement. But – so Poland is quite stable, and we are not seeing – at least for the time being deterioration. On leasing, Sergio will give you the details.

So on leasing, as I mentioned before, as for Italy we had the same issues in respect of implementation of our new model. So this number needs to be normalized for this adjustment. And also clearly we had some migration of impaired loans mainly in the doubtful loans and – so and . I think that you have clearly, as I said before, this cannot be taken as an annualized number. And we will in any case also need to take in consideration that the underlying assets and the recovering of those assets despite the difficult market environment make it – put us in a much more comfortable position in terms of recovering values and protecting the asset values. So – but again also like for Italy I think that we have to really adjust this number due to this new modeling that we implemented at the end of March.

In respect of the LBO portfolio, there is no change compared to the year-end and there is – geared around 300 million of new business. The business activity is still there but at much lower pace than we saw in the second half of 2008, and as I said before the quality of the portfolio remains unchanged. We have around 8.7 billion of exposure with around 160 million underlying. So, no change.
As far as the increase in commissions that we mainly catch in Italy versus Germany, the main driver is a surge in the sale of bancassurance product, especially traditional policies.
Thank you very much.
The next question is from Mr. Matteo Ghilotti of Equita. Please go ahead, sir.

Growth in watchlist loans that was very strong in the quarter. And I wonder taken into consideration that watchlist were already growing in the fourth quarter of 2008, why this has not led in your opinion to increase in NPLs. So I was surprised to see that gross NPLs were flat quarter-on-quarter. So why there was not an increase in NPLs, and if you believe that the strong growth in watchlist will inevitably lead to increasing loan loss provisions? So my point is the 109 basis points of the first quarter probably are not sustainable for the full year. If you agree on this point?
The second question is on the payout policy, if we can assume that, let's say, barring unexpected events UniCredit will pay dividend this year?

And a final question on the net interest income, in the retail segment in Italy in particular was clearly down €200 million quarter-on-quarter. If we can assume that this trend is going to accelerate in the next quarters because of the trend in Euribor rates or a slowdown? Thank you.

Start to answer from the payout policies and Karl will talk of – Karl Guha of the watchlist versus NPLs and Roberto of net interest margin for retail Italy. Clearly payout policy will be defined at the year-end by the board, is related on the capital base we will have at the year-end. So clearly, we are continuously working on the capital base. You're seeing the reduction we're having in terms of risk-weighted assets while we are continuously supporting small and medium size enterprises. So it's a really tight way we are moving in, but we'll see at the year-end the capital position, considering also all the other activities we will be able to realize in terms of capital generation. Talking about watchlist, Karl?

I think there are three comments I'd like to make. The first one I think it's reasonable for you to expect continuing – a slight continuing deterioration in credit portfolios. It's just a straightforward lag effect that you see in credit portfolios across the board, and I think you will see it in every single participant in this industry.

The second part of your answer really is the composition of what's flowing into the overall impaired loans. As you know that there are four specific categories within that, so depending on which category the contribution is. At the moment the watchlist is one of the first ones. It's obviously increasing and we're trying to do that also in a preemptive sense so that we are able to take managerial actions upfront to fix it. So what you do see is a contribution of increasing at that at end which allows us to deal with the underlying collateralization or restructuring. objective, of course, is to avoid any default is as such the objective. So, we have look into each of the compositions and de-composite in order to get a better view and understanding of it. But at this stage the largest contribution is on the watchlist.

To interpret the net interest margin evolution, you have to look at three factors. First of all, clearly the most important one is drop in the interest rates. That has been steady throughout Q1, in a way we went Q2 at the lower level. Now this means that Q1 did not have fully the impact of the drop of net interest rate.

The other aspect to keep in mind is that we've been very, very cautious in terms of new asset generation; in fact, in terms of revenues on risk weighted assets there is a very good improvement of the results in the quarter compared to the previous quarter because especially mortgager money is an area which we are not renewing mortgage that don't give margins positive enough to generate a positive EBITDA.

The other aspect to keep in mind instead is a lag in the re-pricing effect that we can do on the lending side, that typically will a positive effect during Q2. All of this to say that we overall expect Q2 to be the Balkan in terms of net interest margin. Sorry, one point that before I mentioned regarding fees is that in reality in light of the improvement that we have been seeing in the financial market, these might lead us to be slightly more optimistic moving forward. For instance, in the most sensitive piece of our business, overall we in Italy being Fineco we have been in the last weeks and a normal surge of trading activities and that typically is a first signal of potential increases moving on, on the let's say more traditional retail business.

Okay. And just as a follow-up because on the loan loss provision. Sorry, so I don't understand, if you share the view that the annualized 109 basis points of the first quarter as a cost of risk anyway is too optimistic for a full year projection at this stage or it's impossible to say? Thank you.
Yes. We have a range today, so you are partially right because today we are working with a range which is between 115, 125 basis points. So this is the range on which we are working today.
Thank you.
The next question is from Mr. Pascal Decque of Natixis. Please go ahead, sir.

Yes. Good morning. I still have three questions. The first one is regarding the classification once more but rather the one you did in Q3. You didn't mention what impact there was on your P&L from the first reclassification in Q1 '09?
The second one is, have you any target regarding the evolution of the risk weighted asset for the group for the full year?

And the third one, regard the government bonds of 4 billion you were talking about already in the last quarter presentation. That 4 billion – my question is when – what is the split between Italy and Austria? And then what is the method we could – in which we could treat them? I mean, this is a payment of dividend then directly in the balance sheet, not through the P&L. But shall we have like the French bank do, to have a dilution in term of earnings per share, in term of new share just because of these government bonds? Thank you.

Sorry, the impact of the reclassification, as I said before, is negligible is . Okay, sorry. The new reclassification of the impact, as I said before, is negligible is at €13 million – 13, so it's completely negligible. The overall impact of the reclassification is €260 million, also considering this 13 and what we have reclassified in the past. I think that what we have seen today in the market in terms of spreads is a clear demonstration that the reclassification was proper, because clearly there was a matter of liquidity, there is a matter of liquidity in terms of pricing these instruments, and the volatility we are seeing is showing clearly that also considering, as Alessandro was saying before, our aim in terms of position vis-à-vis this stock, these bonds, it was correct the reclassification.

Talking of the split between Germany and Italy – sorry, Austria and Italy, for the government bonds, we have never posted the number we , but as you know the cost is pretty similar on one side and the other. You can – if you want a model that consider one up and one off but there could be some small delta vis-à-vis this average.

Talking of dilution, as you know, these are not instruments that are creating a dilution on the net profit and earnings per share. There is a cost that you have to model as interest margin because our bonds and we – sorry interest margin that goes directly to the capital. So in reality it is not having any impact on the profit and loss. It is reducing the capital base. So it depends on how your model is built because clearly you have to consider in terms of capital reduction the cost for these instruments and it's relatively easy to calculate that.

Okay. I'm sorry, just a quick follow-up on that. The has been fairly creative in a very similar way through the French government bonds. And the French banks are using this kind of bonds which are paying a coupon which is deducted from the capital exactly just like you said. Being, nevertheless, core equity, the French bank themselves and DMT indicated very clearly in the presentation written on a slide that you have to take dilution into effect even if there are non-working share. You use their advice – the analyst to taking into account for dilution in the earnings per share, and I just have a little problem there in term of comparison between one country to the other in term of doing my job.

Sure. It's exactly what I've said. I said that the cost of these bonds will have a direct impact on the equity. We have never provided earnings per share, so it's impossible for me to say what is the impact on the earnings per share. So when you are modeling our net profit for the year-end, we have a certain net profit. You model the capital as well. As we know, there are other elements that are having an impact, for instance, for the French bank the negative available-for-sales is not deducted from the capital, for instance, while we are deducting from the capital this number. But again, then you go to the capital considering other elements, forex translation effect for presence in Central Eastern Europe, available-for-sales reserve, risk-weighted asset growth, and earnings retained; you deduct the cost of the bond and at the end you have a new capital. So we're completely transparent as the French bank.
Okay.
The next question is from Ms. Anna Benassi of Banca Leonardo. Please go ahead, madam.
